original_title: India’s Gautam Adani meets Sri Lanka president to discuss energy, other investments
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka President Ranil Wickremesinghe has met Indian business tycoon Gautam Adani who heads the Adani Group to discuss a number of projects in the island nation.

Adani tweeted Friday July 21 morning that the two discussed a “fascinating set of projects in Sri Lanka” including continued development of the  Colombo Port’s West Container Terminal, a 500-megawatt wind project, and extending the Adani Group’s renewal energy expertise to produce green hydrogen.

Great Honour to have met H.E. President Ranil Wickremesinghe to discuss a fascinating set of projects in Sri Lanka including continued development of Colombo Port West Container Terminal, 500 MW wind project, and extending our renewal energy expertise to produce green Hydrogen. pic.twitter.com/Rsw9dJRhdU
President Wickremesinghe is on a two-day official visit to India at the invitation of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
The Adani Group’s investment on two wind-power projects in Mannar and Pooneryn, in Sri Lanka’s formerly war-torn north, has been controversial.
The MOU for the project was signed on March 11, 2022, with provisional approval given by Sri Lanka’s Sustainable Energy Authority on 10 August 2022.
Meanwhile, the Colombo Port’s West Container Terminal (WCT), a joint venture between the Adani group and Sri Lanka’s John Keells Holdings started dredging work in November 2022 after some delays.

The WCT was given to the Indian firm for a JV after former Sri Lankan prime minister Mahinda Rajapaksa unilaterally cancelled a signed deal to give partially built East Container terminal (ECT) in early 2021.

Wickremesinghe also met India’s minister of external affairs S Jaishankar on Thursday, ahead of a meeting with Modi scheduled for the next day, as well as India’s National Security Advisor Ajit Doval.
Honoured  to call on President Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka during his India visit.

Confident that his meeting with PM @narendramodi tomorrow will further strengthen our neighborly bonds and take forward India’s Neighbourhood First and SAGAR policies.@RW_UNP pic.twitter.com/BiHsgVbhqG
Jaishankar said in January that India plans to encourage greater investments in Sri Lanka’s economy, particularly in energy, tourism and infrastructure development.

India is counting on Sri Lankan authorities’ facilitating a more business-friendly environment, he said during an official visit to the island in January amid reports that the regional power has been looking to cement its growing presence in Sri Lanka in a bid to counter decades of Chinese influence.
President Wickremesinghe told a business forum of Indian chief executives in Colombo on July 17 that Sri Lanka would like to see the Indian rupee used as much as the US dollar. (Colombo/Jul21/2023)
